findings.title: Potential failure to handle transfers of non-compliant ERC-20 tokens
findings.description: In the current implementation, the EigenpieStaking and the NodeDelegator contracts directly call the transfer and transferFrom functions of ERC-20 tokens. However, if a token does not strictly follow the ERC-20 standard (for example, the USDT token), the check on the return value may fail.

findings.title: Potential griefing attack by donating to node delegator
findings.description: A malicious user could potentially donate tokens to manipulate the exchange rate and carry out a griefing attack, severely impairing the contract's functionality and resulting in substantial losses for users.

findings.title: Potential centralization risk
findings.description: There are some potential centralization risks in the project. Specifically, the manager of the EigenpieStaking contract is able to withdraw arbitrary assets and manage funds in permitted node delegators. Additionally, the node delegator array can be arbitrarily configured by the manager.

findings.title: Potential front-running risk
findings.description: The exchangeRateToLST variable of a receipt token is updated periodically, which introduces the risk of front-running.

findings.title: Griefing attacks
findings.description: A malicious user could potentially donate tokens to manipulate the exchange rate and carry out a griefing attack, resulting in substantial losses for users.

findings.title: Non-withdrawable shares are a feature by design
findings.description: The current share minting logic allows malicious users to donate tokens and manipulate the exchange rate, potentially leading to griefing attacks.
